Ingredients:
Carrots
    Parsley root (small)
    Celery root (1/2)
    Small onion
    Optional: Fresh shelled peas or a piece of cauliflower
    Potatoes (2-3, diced)
    Water
    Sour cream
    Fresh butter
    Dill (for garnishing)
    Optional for thickening: Margarine and flour (for roux)
Instructions:
Chop the carrots, parsley root, celery root, and small onion into small cubes.
    Optional: If using, prepare the fresh shelled peas or cauliflower by cleaning and cutting them into small pieces.
    In a pot, pour enough boiling water (approximately 2 cups) over the chopped vegetables.
    Simmer the vegetables over low heat for 15 minutes.
    After 15 minutes, add the diced potatoes to the pot.
    Pour another 1/2 cup of water into the pot.
    Continue cooking the soup for an additional 20 minutes.
    Check the vegetables for tenderness. They should be soft but not overcooked.
    Season the soup with a spoonful of sour cream or add a teaspoon of fresh butter. Stir well.
    Optionally, sprinkle finely chopped dill on top of the soup when serving.
    Alternatively, for a thicker soup, prepare a roux by melting a teaspoon of margarine in a pan and adding a teaspoon of flour. Stir continuously until the mixture turns pale yellow.
    Gradually add small portions of the soup to the roux while stirring vigorously to prevent lumps from forming. Continue until you have about one and a half cups of diluted roux.
    Pour the diluted roux back into the pot with the soup and briefly bring it to a boil again.
    Serve the soup hot.

Ingredients:
Eggs
    Water
    Salt
    Vinegar (potentially for rinsing)
    Pepper (mentioned as an optional addition)
    Chives or green parsley leaves (mentioned as optional garnishes)
    Bread (dark, rye, or whole-grain)
    Butter
Instructions:
Start by washing the eggs thoroughly with water or, preferably, rinse them with a salt-dampened cloth soaked in vinegar. This helps remove any potential bacteria from the eggshell.
    Fill a pot with enough boiling water so that it starts boiling again immediately after adding the eggs. Adding salt to the water can help prevent the eggs from cracking.
    Gently lower the eggs into the boiling water and set a timer for approximately 3 minutes (time may vary depending on desired yolk consistency).
    While the eggs are boiling, prepare any desired garnishes or accompaniments, such as chopping chives or parsley leaves.
    Once the timer goes off, carefully remove the eggs from the boiling water using a slotted spoon or tongs, and transfer them to an eggcup or a heatproof container.
    To serve, either eat the soft-boiled eggs directly from the eggcup or delicately remove the top part of the shell and place the egg in a warmed cup or bowl. The eggs can be enjoyed with or without additional seasonings like salt, pepper, or herbs.
    Optionally, serve the soft-boiled eggs with slices of bread, preferably dark, rye, or whole-grain, accompanied by a spread of butter. Chopped chives or parsley can be sprinkled over the eggs or used as a garnish for the bread.

Ingredients:
Eggs
    Salt
    Pepper
    Chopped chives or parsley (optional)
    Mustard (optional)
    Freshly grated horseradish (optional)
Instructions:
Follow the initial steps of washing the eggs thoroughly.
    Fill a pot with enough boiling water to fully submerge the eggs.
    Gently lower the eggs into the boiling water and set a timer for 4 to 5 minutes.

Ingredients:
Eggs
    Water
    Salt
    Vinegar or lemon juice (optional)
Instructions:
Fill a large pot with water and bring it to a gentle boil.
    Add salt to the water, and if desired, a splash of vinegar or lemon juice. The vinegar or lemon juice helps the eggs coagulate faster and maintain their shape.
    Carefully crack an egg into a small bowl or cup, making sure not to break the yolk.
    Create a gentle whirlpool in the boiling water by stirring it with a spoon.
    Slowly and carefully slide the egg into the center of the whirlpool. The swirling water will help the egg white wrap around the yolk.
    Poach the egg for about 3 minutes for a soft, runny yolk or adjust the cooking time to achieve the desired level of doneness.
    Using a slotted spoon or a mesh sieve, remove the poached egg from the water and place it on a plate lined with a paper towel to drain excess water.
    Season the poached egg with salt and pepper or any other desired herbs and spices.

Ingredients:
Eggs
    Lettuce leaves
    Salt
    Chives or paprika
    Bread or toast
    Butter
Instructions: Place each egg on a lettuce leaf, lightly season with salt, and sprinkle with chives or paprika. Serve with bread or toast spread with butter. You can also eat the lettuce leaves along with the eggs.

Ingredients:
Eggs
    Tomatoes
    Lettuce leaves
    Salt
    Chives
    Pâté
    Slices of bread
Instructions:
Slice the tomatoes in half and scoop out the seeds with a spoon, leaving hollow halves.
    Sprinkle the tomato halves with salt and chives.
    Place the prepared eggs on the tomato halves.
    Arrange the egg-topped tomatoes on lettuce leaves for serving.
    Optionally, you can fry the tomato halves in butter or margarine before placing the eggs on them. This adds more flavor but requires additional preparation.
    Serve with bread or toast spread with pâté.

Ingredients: Eggs
Instructions:
Place the eggs in hot water and let them cook for 10-15 minutes. If you remember them a minute later, it's not a disaster.
    Immediately after removing the eggs from the heat, immerse them in cold water. This step is beneficial as it makes peeling the eggs much easier and quicker.
    If you're taking the hard-boiled eggs on a trip or for a second breakfast, keep them in their shells and peel them just before eating. Hard-boiled eggs in their shells can be stored for up to 12 hours in summer (but not in direct sunlight) and even longer in winter.
    For serving, you can halve, quarter, or slice the hard-boiled eggs. Place them on bread spread with butter and season them according to your preference with chives, pepper, paprika, or a thin layer of mustard. They go well with raw tomatoes, radishes, and cucumbers.
    If you have the time, inclination, and necessary ingredients, you can create visually appealing and delicious dishes using hard-boiled eggs, especially as appetizers.

Ingredients:
Hard-boiled eggs
    Onion (finely chopped)
    Butter (1 tablespoon)
    Sour cream (1 tablespoon)
    Chopped chives (1 teaspoon)
    Salt and pepper to taste
    Bread crumbs for coating
Instructions:
Hard-boil the eggs and let them cool.
Carefully cut each egg in half lengthwise, keeping the shells intact.
Gently remove the yolks and finely chop them.
In a small skillet or pan, lightly sauté the finely chopped onion in butter.
Combine the sautéed onion, chopped egg yolks, sour cream, chopped chives, salt, and pepper in a bowl. Mix well until the filling is smooth and creamy.
Spoon the filling mixture back into the hollowed egg white halves, filling them evenly.
Roll the filled eggs in bread crumbs to coat them.
Serve the stuffed eggs as an appetizer or part of a meal

Ingredients:
Hard-boiled eggs
    Onion (finely chopped)
    Butter (1 tablespoon)
    Bread crumbs
    Raw egg (optional, for binding)
Instructions:
Hard-boil the eggs and let them cool.
    Carefully cut each egg in half lengthwise, keeping the shells intact.
    Gently remove the yolks and finely chop them.
    In a small skillet or pan, lightly sauté the finely chopped onion in butter.
    Combine the sautéed onion, chopped egg yolks, bread crumbs, salt, and pepper in a bowl. Mix well.
    If the mixture is not binding well, you can add a raw egg to help hold it together.
    Shape the mixture into small patties or croquettes.
    Roll the croquettes in bread crumbs to coat them.
    Heat butter in a skillet and fry the croquettes until golden brown on each side.
    Serve the egg croquettes as a side dish or part of a meal.

Enjoy your stuffed eggs and egg croquettes!

Time: hard-boiled eggs with ham, beef tenderloin, or herring:
Ingredients:
Hard-boiled eggs
    Slices of ham, beef tenderloin (raw), or herring fillets
    Lettuce leaves
    Vegetable salad (optional)
    Raw tomatoes
    Cucumbers (raw or pickled)
    Pickles or pickled plums (optional)
Instructions:
Hard-boil the eggs and let them cool.
    Peel the eggs, ensuring they are fully and neatly peeled.
    Take a slice of ham, beef tenderloin, or half a herring fillet and wrap it around the whole egg. The slice should be slightly narrower than the egg.
    Place the wrapped egg on a lettuce leaf for presentation.
    Alternatively, you can place a spoonful of vegetable salad (such as mixed diced vegetables) on a lettuce leaf and place the wrapped egg on top.
    If using herring, you can serve it with herring salad instead.
    To garnish the plate, you can add quartered raw tomatoes and cucumbers. In winter, you can use slices of pickled cucumbers, pickles, or pickled plums.

Time: hard-boiled eggs with spicy cold sauces,
Ingredients:
Hard-boiled eggs (peeled and halved)
    Spicy sauces such as chive sauce, mustard sauce, or horseradish sauce
    Chopped chives for garnish
Instructions:
Place the peeled and halved hard-boiled eggs on a small platter or plate. Pour the chive sauce, mustard sauce, or horseradish sauce over the eggs. You can refer to the "Sauces" section for specific recipes.    Another presentation method is to pour a small amount of sauce onto a shallow dish or small plate, ensuring that it doesn't completely cover the eggs. Arrange the halved eggs, cut side up, on the sauce. Sprinkle chopped chives over each egg for added flavor and garnish.

Remember to adjust the quantities of the sauces and garnishes according to your preference and the number of servings you are preparing.

Time: with herring, ham, sausage, or cheese,
Ingredients:
Hard-boiled eggs (peeled and halved)
    Additional ingredients of your choice: herring, ham, sausage, or cheese
    1 tablespoon of thick sour cream
    Salt to taste
    Lettuce leaves for serving
    Optional: thick tartar sauce or mayonnaise (refer to the "Sauces" section for recipes)
Instructions:
Carefully remove the yolks from the peeled and halved eggs. Finely chop the yolks or pass them through a grinder or food processor. You can use 5 grams of ham, sausage, or cheese or half of a well-soaked herring for every 2 yolks.
    Mix the finely chopped yolks with your chosen additional ingredient. Add 1 tablespoon of thick sour cream and check the seasoning, adding salt as needed.
    Fill the egg whites generously with the yolk mixture.
    Serve the stuffed eggs on lettuce leaves or pour a thick tartar sauce or mayonnaise over them.

Note: Making mayonnaise from scratch requires some practice, but it can be worth the effort to impress your guests. Please remember that our recipes and tips have been thoroughly tested.

Ingredients:
Eggs
    Cooking fat (butter, bacon fat, lard, or vegetable oil)
    Salt and pepper (to taste)

That's it! Fried eggs are a simple and versatile dish that requires minimal ingredients. Adjust the quantity of eggs and seasonings based on your preferences and the number of servings you want to make. Enjoy your delicious fried eggs!
Instructions:
Here are two methods to prepare fried eggs:

    Simple Method:
        Heat a small frying pan and add the cooking fat of your choice (enough to coat the bottom of the pan).
        Carefully crack the egg into the pan, ensuring not to break the yolk. Season with salt.
        Once the egg white starts to set, pierce the yolk gently with a fork. This will help it cook evenly.
        If the pan is not non-stick, transfer the fried egg onto a plate. Serve it with bread, dipping it into the hot fat. Enjoy!

    Enhanced Method:
        In a small frying pan or saucepan, melt a teaspoon of butter or margarine and add a tablespoon of sour cream.
        Once the sour cream starts to simmer, carefully crack two eggs into the pan, side by side. Sprinkle them lightly with salt and top with grated Tilsit cheese or any other dry cheese.
        Avoid stirring the eggs. Allow the egg whites to set slowly while you eagerly anticipate their deliciousness.
        Once the egg whites are fully cooked, remove the pan from heat and serve the eggs directly from the pan or transfer them to a plate. Eggs cooked in a pan or skillet tend to be more flavorful.

In a frying pan, melt a teaspoon of bacon fat or cooking fat over medium heat.
    Add 3-4 slices of bacon, bacon fat, sausage, or ham to the pan. Cook until the bacon starts to render its fat and becomes slightly translucent, and the sausage or ham begins to brown.
    Flip the bacon or sausage slices to the other side and create space for the eggs.
    Crack 2 eggs into the pan, taking care not to break the yolks. Season with salt and pepper.
    Cook until the egg whites are set, but the yolks are still runny or cooked to your desired doneness. If you prefer well-done eggs, you can cook them longer.
    Once the eggs are cooked, remove them from the pan immediately.
    Garnish with chopped chives or parsley if desired.
    Serve the fried eggs with bacon, sausage, or ham alongside toast or bread.

Feel free to adjust the quantities and cooking times based on your preferences. Enjoy your delicious fried eggs with your choice of sides!

Eggs

    Sausage slices or diced sausage
    Ham slices
    Cooking fat (butter or oil) if using ham instead of bacon or sausage
    Salt and pepper (to taste)
    Chopped chives or parsley for garnish (optional)
    Toast or bread, for serving

2-3 eggs
    Butter, margarine, or lard
    Salt to taste
    Optional: Water or milk (1 tablespoon)

Note: You can also add additional ingredients of your choice, such as cheese, herbs, vegetables, or cooked meats, to enhance the flavor of the scrambled eggs.
Instructions:
However, we believe that 2 eggs (exceptionally 3) are a completely satisfying amount to appease the appetite, especially when accompanied by a portion of potatoes (fried or boiled), a slice of bread with butter, not to mention green salad, tomatoes, or cucumber salad.

Scrambled eggs can be prepared perfectly just as easily as they can be ruined. They should be moist and, depending on our preference, almost runny or with a thick creamy consistency. Overcooked eggs are dry, "grainy," and devoid of the characteristic aroma that is one of the important charms of this dish.

Always fry scrambled eggs over low heat!

2 eggs are the "golden measure." We crack them into a saucepan or onto a plate and beat them lightly with a fork until the resulting "emulsion" starts to froth slightly on the surface. The more thoroughly we beat the eggs, the more delicate and "fluffy" the scrambled eggs will be.

In a frying pan, melt a heaping teaspoon of butter, margarine, or lard. Butter gives the scrambled eggs a specially mild aroma. The fat should be hot (but never brown the butter). Pour the lightly salted eggs onto the pan (overly salty scrambled eggs are dreadful) and, as they begin to set, mix them with a fork to ensure even cooking. Adding a tablespoon of water (preferably mineral water) or milk to the eggs before beating them will increase the volume and make them even more delicate.    2 teaspoons of grated cheese (added just before pouring the eggs onto the pan)
    Optional: 1 tablespoon of cooked peas, finely chopped sausage or ham, or sautéed mushrooms
    Finely chopped chives or spring onions for garnishing
    Serve with fried potatoes and pickles for a complete meal
    Optional: A few leaves of green salad (except in winter months) for serving

These additional ingredients will enhance the flavor, nutritional value, and appearance of the scrambled eggs.

Instructions:
Crack the eggs into a bowl and beat them lightly with a fork or whisk.
    Add water or milk to the beaten eggs and continue to mix until well combined. This will help make the omelette fluffy.
    Season the egg mixture with salt according to your taste preferences.
    Heat a frying pan over medium heat and add the butter. Allow it to melt and coat the pan evenly.
    Once the butter is melted and sizzling, pour the beaten egg mixture into the pan in a swift and decisive motion.
    Tilt the pan in different directions to ensure that the egg mixture spreads evenly across the surface of the pan.
    After a few seconds, when the edges of the omelette start to set, gently shake the pan to check if the omelette is sticking to the bottom.
    If the omelette is sticking, carefully loosen it with a knife, being cautious not to tear the omelette.
    Cook the omelette until the surface is slightly sticky but not runny, and the bottom is nicely browned. You can check the readiness by gently lifting the edge of the omelette.
    Once the omelette is cooked to your liking, slide it onto a plate using a spatula or by flipping it over.
    Serve the omelette immediately while it is still hot and enjoy its deliciousness.

Ingredients:
2 egg yolks
    2 egg whites
    1 heaping teaspoon of flour
    1 tablespoon of milk
    A pinch of salt

These are the basic ingredients for the alternative omelette. You can also choose to add various fillings or toppings of your choice, such as:

    Spinach
    Green peas
    Salad vegetables
    Butter-fried tomatoes
    Mushrooms
    Brains (presumably referring to a type of offal)
    Smoked pickling (preserved food)
    Chopped ham or sausage
    Chives, dill, and parsley (for the herb mixture)
Instructions:
In a small saucepan, mix a heaping teaspoon of flour with a tablespoon of milk until there are no lumps (it's important to avoid any lumps).
    Add two egg yolks to the mixture and stir well with a spoon for at least one minute.
    Add a pinch of salt to the mixture.
    In a separate plate, beat two egg whites with a fork until stiff peaks form (the egg whites should be cold, and the plate should not be greasy).
    Gently fold the beaten egg whites into the mixture of yolks, flour, and milk.
    Heat a frying pan and pour the mixture onto the pan.
    Proceed with cooking the omelette as you would for a regular French omelette.
    Once cooked, you can serve the omelette as is, or if you enjoy legumes, you can spread any jam or preserves on top, fold it or roll it into a roll, sprinkle it with powdered sugar, or drizzle it with raspberry or cherry juice.
    This makes for a wonderful meal, even for special occasions!

Ingredients:
1 egg yolk
    2 tablespoons of sugar
    Optional variations:
        A shot of white wine
        1 teaspoon of cocoa or Nesquik
        1 tablespoon of fresh blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, or even wild strawberries
        1/2 teaspoon of vanilla sugar
Instructions:
After removing the embryo, vigorously whisk the egg yolk in a cup or porcelain mug with 2 tablespoons of sugar until the mixture turns white and doubles in volume. This process takes at least 10 minutes. Listening to the radio can make the whisking more enjoyable.
    For different variations, you can add a shot of white wine, cocoa or Nesquik, fresh berries, or a hint of vanilla sugar.
    Mix the added ingredients well with the beaten egg yolk and sugar.
    Kogel-mogel can be enjoyed as a standalone dessert, but it pairs exceptionally well with sponge cake.

Kogel-mogel is highly recommended, especially for students during late-night study sessions before exams. The variation with Nesquik and fruits creates a delicious and attractive treat. Enjoy this perfect dessert, and it will surely bring you delight during your study breaks!

Painting Easter eggs may not be considered a culinary skill, but forgetting about Easter eggs on Easter would be a huge mistake. Placing two or three eggs on a clay plate (a wide selection available in any Cepelia store) has the power to make us smile involuntarily just by looking at them. Let's cast a glance at them while eating, and even bread with sausage (if we don't have any other Easter specialty) will acquire a special "Easter" flavor.

Hard-boiled eggs left in their shells can come in handy for an old Polish social game practiced by youth in the 15th century called "wałatka."
The rules of the game are simple: we hit our eggs against each other. The one whose egg cracks loses. The winner can, of course (and should!), demand a reward. (However, the cracked egg must be eaten beforehand).

Ingredients:
1 and 1/4 cups of boiling water
    1 teaspoon of "chicken broth" extract
    Salt to taste
    Chopped fresh parsley
    Raw egg yolk (optional)

Note: The "chicken broth" extract refers to a powdered or liquid seasoning that provides the flavor of chicken broth. You can find it in stores labeled as "chicken broth" or "chicken bouillon" extract.
Instructions:
In a cup or bowl, dissolve 1 teaspoon of "chicken broth" extract in 1 and 1/4 cups of boiling water. Stir well until the extract is completely dissolved.

    Taste the broth and if you find it too mild or lacking saltiness, add salt according to your preference. Stir until the salt is dissolved.

    In a serving bowl or cup, sprinkle chopped fresh parsley on top. This will add a touch of freshness and visual appeal to the broth.

    If desired, you can enhance the flavor and nutritional value of the broth by adding a raw egg yolk. Crack an egg, separate the yolk, and gently drop it into the broth in the serving bowl. Be careful not to cook the yolk.

    Optionally, you can serve the chicken broth with a portion of pan-fried potatoes ("odsmażane ziemniaki"). Enjoy the flavorful broth and the satisfying combination of flavors.

Note: This recipe provides a quick and easy way to make chicken broth using an extract, but it may not have the same depth of flavor as traditional homemade broth made from simmering chicken bones and vegetables for a longer period.

Ingredients:
Chicken broth (prepared according to the previous recipe)
    1 teaspoon "chicken broth" extract
    1 and 1/4 cups of boiling water
    1 tablespoon kaszki manna (semolina)
    Salt to taste
    Optional toppings: finely chopped fresh parsley or grated dry cheese

These ingredients will be used to make a delicious and hearty grysikowa soup.
Instructions:
Prepare the chicken broth according to the previous recipe.
    In a separate pot, bring 1 and 1/4 cups of water to a boil.
    Dissolve 1 teaspoon of "chicken broth" extract in the boiling water, stirring well.
    Slowly add 1 tablespoon of kaszki manna (semolina) to the boiling water, stirring constantly to prevent lumps from forming.
    Reduce the heat to low and continue stirring the soup for at least eight minutes. The soup should be simmering gently.
    Taste the soup and add salt if needed, adjusting it to your preference.
    Once the soup is cooked and thickened to a creamy consistency, remove it from the heat.
    Serve the grysikowa soup hot, optionally garnishing it with finely chopped fresh parsley or grated dry cheese.

Enjoy your delicious grysikowa soup!

Ingredients:
Chicken broth: as per the previous recipe
    Grysik (semolina): 1/2 tablespoon
    Ham or sausage: a small piece, finely chopped
Instructions:
Prepare the grysikowa soup as described in the previous recipe, but with a slight modification.
    While preparing the chicken broth, add only 1/2 tablespoon of grysik (semolina) to the boiling broth.
    Allow the soup to cook until the grysik is tender and the soup has thickened to your desired consistency.
    In a separate pan, cook a small piece of finely chopped ham or sausage until it is heated through and slightly browned.
    Once the grysikowa soup is ready, add the cooked ham or sausage to the pot and stir it in.
    Bring the soup to a boil once again, allowing the flavors to blend together.
    Ladle the soup into deep bowls and serve it hot.

Ingredients:
Grysik (semolina): as per the previous recipe
    Chicken broth: as per the previous recipe
    Raw egg yolk: 1
    Lemon juice: juice from 1/4 lemon

These ingredients will add a tangy and refreshing flavor to the grysikowa soup. Make sure to whisk the raw egg yolk thoroughly into the cooked soup before adding the lemon juice. This will create a creamy and flavorful texture. Adjust the amount of lemon juice according to your taste preferences.
Instructions:
Prepare the chicken broth as per the previous recipe. Make sure it is hot and simmering.

    Bread crumbs
    Cooking oil or fat for frying
Instructions:
Place the pork chop on a wooden cutting board and lightly pound it with the handle of a knife. This helps tenderize the meat and make it more tender.
    Lightly season the pork chop with salt on both sides.
    Dredge the pork chop in flour, shaking off any excess.
    Dip the floured pork chop into the beaten egg, ensuring that it is coated evenly on all sides.
    Next, press the pork chop into the bread crumbs, using the back of a fork to ensure an even coating of crumbs on both sides.
    Heat cooking oil or fat in a frying pan over medium heat.
    Once the oil is hot, carefully place the breaded pork chop into the pan. Cook for about 5 minutes on each side, or until the coating is golden brown and crispy.
    Avoid overcooking the pork chop to prevent it from becoming too dry.
    Once cooked, transfer the Kotlet Schabowy to a paper towel-lined plate to absorb any excess oil.
    Serve the breaded pork cutlet hot as a main dish, accompanied by mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a fresh salad.

Enjoy the delicious Kotlet Schabowy "panierowany"!

Ingredients:
1 boneless pork chop (100-120 g)
    Salt
    All-purpose flour
    Cooking oil or fat for frying
Instructions:
Place the pork chop on a wooden cutting board and lightly pound it with the handle of a knife to tenderize it.
    Season the pork chop with salt on both sides.
    Dredge the pork chop in flour, coating it lightly on both sides. Shake off any excess flour.
    Heat cooking oil or fat in a frying pan over medium heat.
    Once the oil is hot, carefully place the floured pork chop into the pan.
    Cook the pork chop for about 5 minutes on each side, or until it is cooked through and golden brown on the outside.
    Avoid overcooking the pork chop to prevent it from becoming too dry.
    Once cooked, transfer the Kotlet Schabowy to a paper towel-lined plate to absorb any excess oil.
    Serve the pork cutlet hot as a main dish, accompanied by mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a fresh salad.

This method involves simply coating the pork chop with flour and frying it without the additional steps of dipping it in beaten egg and bread crumbs. The result is a simpler version of Kotlet Schabowy that still maintains its delicious flavor.

Ingredients:
boneless pork chop (100-120 g)
Salt
Cooking oil or fat for frying
Instructions:
Place the pork chop on a wooden cutting board and lightly pound it with the handle of a knife to tenderize it.
    Season the pork chop with salt on both sides.
    Heat cooking oil or fat in a frying pan over high heat until it is very hot.
    Carefully place the seasoned pork chop directly onto the hot fat in the pan.
    Sear the pork chop for a few minutes on each side until it is cooked through and golden brown on the outside.
    Adjust the heat if necessary to ensure the pork chop cooks evenly without burning.
    Once cooked, transfer the Kotlet Schabowy to a paper towel-lined plate to remove any excess oil.
    Serve the pork cutlet hot as a main dish, accompanied by mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a fresh salad.

This method skips the step of coating the pork chop with flour or dipping it in beaten egg and bread crumbs. Instead, the seasoned pork chop is seared directly in hot oil or fat, resulting in a simple and flavorful Kotlet Schabowy.

Ingredients:
1 boneless pork chop (100-120 g)
    Salt
    Ground black pepper
    Cooking oil or fat for frying
    1 apple, cored and thinly sliced
    1 tablespoon butter
    1 tablespoon sugar
    1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
Instructions:
Season the pork chop with salt and pepper on both sides.
    Heat cooking oil or fat in a frying pan over medium-high heat.
    Carefully place the seasoned pork chop in the hot pan and cook for a few minutes on each side until it is cooked through and golden brown. Adjust the heat if needed to prevent burning.
    While the pork chop is cooking, prepare the caramelized apples. In a separate pan, melt the butter over medium heat.
    Add the sliced apples, sugar, and ground cinnamon to the pan with butter. Cook the apples, stirring occasionally, until they are tender and lightly caramelized.
    Once the pork chop is cooked, remove it from the pan and transfer it to a plate.
    Serve the pork chop topped with the caramelized apples.
    Accompany the dish with your choice of side dishes, such as mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a fresh salad.

The combination of the juicy pork chop and sweet caramelized apples adds a delightful twist to the traditional Kotlet Schabowy. Enjoy your meal!

Ingredients:
boneless pork chop (100-120 g)
Salt
Ground black pepper
Cooking oil or fat for frying
1 onion, thinly sliced
Mustard (optional)
Instructions:
Season the pork chop with salt and pepper on both sides.
    Heat cooking oil or fat in a frying pan over medium-high heat.
    Carefully place the seasoned pork chop in the hot pan and cook for a few minutes on each side until it is cooked through and golden brown. Adjust the heat if needed to prevent burning.
    After cooking the pork chop for about 2 minutes on each side, add the thinly sliced onion to the pan next to the chop. Stir the onions occasionally with a fork to avoid burning.
    Continue cooking the pork chop and onions together until the onions are soft and lightly caramelized.
    Once the pork chop is cooked and the onions are caramelized, remove them from the pan and transfer them to a plate.
    Serve the pork chop topped with the caramelized onions.
    If desired, accompany the dish with a dollop of mustard on the side for added flavor.
    Enjoy the juicy and tender pork chop with the flavorful caramelized onions.

Remember, a properly cooked kotlet schabowy should be juicy and tender. Enjoy your meal!

Ingredients:
Veal cutlets
    Salt
    Ground black pepper
    All-purpose flour
    Eggs
    Bread crumbs
    Cooking oil or fat for frying
Instructions:
Season the veal cutlets with salt and pepper on both sides.
    Prepare three shallow bowls or plates: one with flour, one with beaten eggs, and one with bread crumbs.
    Dredge each veal cutlet in the flour, shaking off any excess.
    Dip the floured cutlet into the beaten eggs, allowing any excess to drip off.
    Coat the cutlet with bread crumbs, pressing gently to ensure the crumbs adhere to the meat.
    Heat cooking oil or fat in a frying pan over medium-high heat.
    Carefully place the breaded veal cutlets in the hot pan and cook for a few minutes on each side until they are cooked through and golden brown. Adjust the heat if needed to prevent burning.
    Once the veal cutlets are cooked, transfer them to a paper towel-lined plate to drain any excess oil.
    Serve the veal cutlets hot, accompanied by your choice of side dishes, such as mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a fresh salad.

Note: Cooking times may vary depending on the thickness of the veal cutlets. It's essential to cook them until they reach a safe internal temperature and are no longer pink in the center.

Enjoy your delicious veal cutlets!

Ingredients:
Veal cutlets
    All-purpose flour
    Salt
    Pepper
    Cooking fat (such as oil or butter)
    Sour cream
Instructions:
Prepare the veal cutlets, removing any excess fat and place them on a cutting board.
    In a bowl, place the all-purpose flour and lightly season with salt and pepper.
    Dredge the veal cutlets in the flour, making sure they are evenly coated. Shake off any excess flour.
    Heat the cooking fat in a frying pan over medium heat.
    Add the veal cutlets to the hot fat and fry on both sides until they turn golden brown and are well cooked. Make sure they are cooked through. The cooking time will depend on the thickness of the cutlets.
    Once the veal cutlets are done, transfer them to a plate and cover with aluminum foil to keep them warm.
    In the same pan, pour a tablespoon of sour cream and heat it over medium heat, stirring, until the sour cream is heated through and combines with the juices and fat from the pan.
    Pour the prepared cream sauce over the veal cutlets.
    Serve the veal cutlets with cream immediately, preferably with your favorite side dishes such as potatoes, salad, or vegetables.

Enjoy your meal!

Ingredients:
Veal escalopes
    All-purpose flour
    Eggs
    Breadcrumbs
    Salt
    Pepper
    Cooking fat (such as oil or clarified butter)
    Lemon wedges (for serving)
Instructions:
Place the veal escalopes on a cutting board and lightly pound them with the flat side of a meat mallet. Be careful not to tear the meat, but ensure that it is evenly flattened.
    Season the escalopes with salt and pepper on both sides.
    Prepare three separate shallow bowls or plates. Place the flour in one, beaten eggs in another, and breadcrumbs in the third.
    Dredge each veal escalope in flour, shaking off any excess.
    Dip the floured escalope into the beaten eggs, making sure it is coated on both sides.
    Press the escalope firmly into the breadcrumbs, ensuring an even coating. Repeat this process for each escalope.
    Heat the cooking fat in a large frying pan over medium heat.
    Carefully place the breaded veal escalopes into the hot fat and fry them until golden brown on both sides. Cook each side for a few minutes, until the breadcrumbs are crispy and the veal is cooked through. You may need to do this in batches, depending on the size of your pan.
    Once cooked, transfer the schnitzels to a plate lined with paper towels to absorb any excess oil.
    Serve the Wiener schnitzel hot, accompanied by lemon wedges for squeezing over the meat. Traditionally, it is served with a side of potato salad or fries.

Ingredients:
Beef tenderloin (polędwica wołowa)
    Flour (for breading)
    Salt (to season the meat)
    Fat or oil (for frying)
    Optional: Fresh butter
    Optional: Finely chopped parsley or chives
    Optional: Eggs (for serving with a fried egg on top)
Instructions:
If you managed to acquire beef tenderloin, lightly pound the meat with the handle of a knife, being careful not to pierce it. This will help tenderize the meat.
    Proceed with the preparation as you would with a breaded pork chop (kotlet schabowy). You can follow the steps for breading the meat.
    Lightly coat the beefsteak in flour, making sure it is evenly covered. Shake off any excess flour.
    Heat a generous amount of fat or oil in a pan until it is very hot.
    Place the breaded beefsteak in the hot fat and fry it for about 3 minutes on each side. This will give it a nice golden crust.
    After frying, season the beefsteak with salt while it is still in the pan.
    Once cooked, transfer the beefsteak to a plate.
    For serving, you can add a small piece of fresh butter on top of the beefsteak, mixed with finely chopped parsley or chives for extra flavor. Alternatively, you can serve it with a fried egg on top.
    Enjoy your classic beefsteak "au naturel"!

Remember that a perfectly prepared beefsteak should be juicy and tender. It is normal for the meat to have a pink color inside, so don't be alarmed if you see some reddish juices when you cut into it.

Ingredients:
Beef tenderloin (polędwica wołowa)
    Flour (for breading)
    Salt (to season the meat)
    Fat or oil (for frying)
    Optional: Fresh butter
    Optional: Finely chopped parsley or chives
    Optional: Eggs (for serving with a fried egg on top)
Instructions:
If the beef tenderloin is not already sliced, cut it into thick slices or medallions.
    Lightly pound the meat with a meat mallet or the back of a knife to tenderize it. Be careful not to pierce the meat.
    Season the beefsteak with salt on both sides.
    Coat each piece of beefsteak with flour, shaking off any excess.
    Heat a generous amount of fat or oil in a frying pan over high heat.
    Once the oil is hot, carefully place the beefsteak in the pan and cook for about 3 minutes on each side, or until desired doneness is achieved. Adjust the cooking time according to your preference for rare, medium, or well-done steak.
    Remove the beefsteak from the pan and let it rest for a few minutes before serving.
    Optional: Place a small piece of fresh butter on top of each beefsteak while it is still hot, allowing it to melt and enhance the flavor.
    Optional: Garnish with finely chopped parsley or chives for added freshness.
    Optional: Serve the beefsteak with a fried egg on top for a classic "befsztyk po wiedeńsku" presentation.
    Enjoy your delicious beefsteak!

Ingredients:
Lamb leg slice or lamb shoulder piece (100-120g)
    1 clove of garlic, finely chopped
    Salt and pepper to taste
    Oil or butter for frying

Optional side dishes:

    Roasted vegetables
    Mashed potatoes
    Fresh salad
Instructions:
Take a slice of lamb leg or a piece of lamb shoulder (100-120g) and lightly pound it with a meat mallet to tenderize it.
    Rub the meat with a freshly chopped garlic clove, ensuring both sides are well coated.
    Heat a frying pan over medium-high heat and add a small amount of oil or butter.
    Once the pan is hot, carefully place the lamb steak in the pan.
    Cook the steak for about 3-4 minutes on each side, or until it reaches your desired level of doneness.
    Remove the lamb steak from the pan and let it rest for a few minutes before serving.
    Season with salt and pepper to taste.
    You can serve the lamb steak with your choice of side dishes, such as roasted vegetables, mashed potatoes, or a fresh salad.
    Enjoy the delicious and easily digestible lamb steak!

Note: Cooking times may vary depending on the thickness of the lamb steak and your preferred level of doneness. Make sure to handle and cook the lamb safely, ensuring it reaches a safe internal temperature for consumption.

Ingredients:
Lean pork from the ham (120-150g), cut into small pieces
    Oil or butter for frying
    Salt and pepper to taste

Optional ingredients:

    1 small onion, thinly sliced
    3-5 button mushrooms, finely chopped
Instructions:
Heat some oil or butter in a frying pan over medium heat.
    Add the sliced pork to the hot pan and spread it out in a single layer.
    Cook the pork, stirring frequently, for about 10 minutes or until it is evenly browned and cooked through.
    If desired, add the thinly sliced onion or finely chopped mushrooms to the pan after about 5 minutes of cooking. Continue cooking and stirring until the onions or mushrooms are softened and cooked.
    Season the pork with salt and pepper to taste. Be cautious with the salt if you added the optional ingredients, as they may already contribute some saltiness.
    Continue cooking for another minute or two to allow the flavors to meld.
    Remove the fried pork from the heat and serve hot.

You can enjoy fried pork as a main dish with rice or potatoes, or use it as a filling for sandwiches or wraps. Feel free to customize the recipe by adding herbs, spices, or other ingredients according to your preference.

Ingredients:
250 grams of veal or pork liver
    2 tablespoons of flour
    Salt and pepper to taste
    Cooking oil or butter for frying
    Optional: sliced onions, garlic, herbs, or spices for additional flavor
Instructions:
Rinse the liver under cold water and pat it dry with paper towels.
    Slice the liver into thin, even pieces.
    In a shallow dish, season the flour with salt and pepper. Dredge each piece of liver in the seasoned flour, shaking off any excess.
    Heat a frying pan over medium heat and add a small amount of cooking oil or butter.
    Once the oil or butter is hot, carefully place the liver slices in the pan. If desired, you can also add sliced onions or minced garlic at this point.
    Cook the liver for about 3-4 minutes on each side or until it is browned and cooked through. Be careful not to overcook the liver to avoid it becoming tough and dry.
    If using onions or garlic, sauté them until they are soft and translucent.
    Remove the liver from the pan and transfer it to a plate lined with paper towels to absorb any excess oil.
    Serve the cooked liver immediately while it is still hot. It pairs well with mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a fresh salad.

Note: Liver is best enjoyed when it is cooked to medium or medium-rare to maintain its tenderness and flavor. Adjust the cooking time according to your preference.

Ingredients:
50-200 grams of liver slices (veal or pork)
Flour for dusting
Salt to taste
Cooking oil or butter for frying
Optional: sliced onions for serving
Instructions:
Lightly dust the liver slices with flour, shaking off any excess.
    Heat a frying pan over high heat and add a small amount of cooking oil or butter.
    Once the oil or butter is hot, carefully place the liver slices in the pan. Make sure not to overcrowd the pan; cook the liver in batches if needed.
    Sear the liver on high heat for about 3 minutes on each side, or until browned and cooked through. Cooking time may vary depending on the thickness of the slices and desired doneness. Be careful not to overcook the liver to keep it tender and juicy.
    Once cooked, remove the liver from the pan and place it on a serving plate. Sprinkle with salt to taste.
    Optional: In the same pan, add sliced onions and sauté them until they are caramelized and golden brown. Serve the liver topped with the sautéed onions.
    Serve the pan-fried liver immediately while it is still hot. It can be accompanied by mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a fresh salad.

Note: Liver is best enjoyed when it is cooked to medium or medium-rare to maintain its tenderness and flavor. Adjust the cooking time according to your preference. The center of the liver should still be slightly pink when cooked.

Ingredients:
100 grams of lean ground meat (veal, beef, pork)
    1 raw egg
    1 small piece of bread, soaked in water and squeezed
    Salt to taste
    For the broth: 500 ml of water, 1 small carrot, ½ parsley root, a small piece of celery
    For the dill sauce: dill, broth from cooking the meatballs, and any additional soup of your choice (vegetable, potato, tomato)
    Optional: 1 cube of Maggi seasoning (if cooking in water)

Instructions:
Instructions:
n a bowl, mix the ground meat, raw egg, and squeezed bread. Season with salt according to your taste.
    Form small meatballs about the size of a small egg.
    In a separate pot, bring the water to a boil. Add the carrot, parsley root, and celery to create a flavorful broth. Season the broth with salt.
    Carefully drop the meatballs into the boiling broth. Cook them for 12-15 minutes until they are fully cooked and tender.
    While the meatballs are cooking, prepare the dill sauce. Finely chop the dill.
    In a separate saucepan, combine a portion of the meatball broth with the chopped dill to create a dill sauce. You can also add any additional soup of your choice to the sauce for extra flavor.
    Once the meatballs are cooked, remove them from the broth using a slotted spoon and place them on a serving dish.
    Serve the meatballs with the dill sauce and any accompanying soup or broth. Alternatively, you can cook the meatballs in water with a dissolved Maggi seasoning cube instead of using the vegetable broth.

Enjoy your meatballs!

Ingredients:
A piece of veal, beef, or lean pork (around 300 grams)
    Vegetables for the broth: carrot, parsley root, celery (optional: dried mushroom)
    Water (approximately 800 ml)
    Salt to taste
    Sauce options: dill sauce, horseradish sauce, chive sauce, tomato sauce
    Optional: additional vegetables for salad or soup
Instructions:
Start by preparing the meat. Cut it into large cube-shaped pieces.
    Rinse the meat under running water (do not soak the meat in water before cooking).
    In a pot, bring the water to a boil. Add the meat to the boiling water.
    For a 300-gram piece of meat, use around 800 ml of water. The water level may reduce during cooking, so you can add more boiling water if needed.
    Cook the meat over low heat with the lid on for about 1-2 hours, depending on the type and age of the meat. The meat should become tender and easy to shred.
    After about 30 minutes of cooking, add a few pieces of vegetables to the pot, such as carrot, parsley root, celery, and optionally a dried mushroom for extra flavor.
    Once the meat is tender, season the broth with salt to taste.
    Remove the cooked meat from the broth and set it aside. The broth can be used to make soup or sauce.
    You can use the cooked vegetables to make a salad (see salad recipes) or add them to the soup.
    Serve the cooked meat with your choice of sauce: dill sauce, horseradish sauce, chive sauce, or tomato sauce. In the summer, salads are also recommended to accompany the dish.

Enjoy your meat cooked in vegetable broth!

Ingredients:
Meat of your choice (veal, pork, beef)
    Salt
    Onion
    Water or broth
    Optional: additional seasonings and vegetables of your choice
    Optional: hot water or sour cream to thin or enrich the sauce
Instructions:
Start by blanching the meat. Dip it in boiling water for about 15 seconds to remove any impurities. Pat it dry with a paper towel.
    Lightly season the meat with salt.
    In a small pot or Dutch oven, heat a small amount of oil or fat over high heat. Brown the meat on all sides until it develops a golden-brown color.
    Add finely chopped onion to the pot and continue cooking for a short while until the onion becomes translucent.
    Pour in about 1/2 to 1 cup of water or broth, enough to partially cover the meat.
    Cover the pot with a lid and reduce the heat to low. Allow the meat to simmer gently. If the liquid evaporates too quickly, you can add a little hot water as needed.
    The cooking time will vary depending on the type of meat and its thickness. Veal may take around 40-50 minutes, pork a bit longer, and beef the longest. Check the meat's tenderness by piercing it with a fork.
    Once the meat is tender, remove it from the pot and transfer it to a serving dish.
    If desired, thicken or enrich the sauce in the pot. You can do this by adding a spoonful of hot water and bringing it to a boil, or by stirring in a spoonful of sour cream.
    Pour the sauce over the cooked meat and serve.

You can accompany the braised meat with side dishes such as mashed potatoes, steamed vegetables, or a salad. Enjoy your braised meat with its flavorful sauce!

Ingredients:
150 grams of meat (beef, pork, or a combination)
    Salt
    Onion
    Flour (optional)
    Water or broth
Instructions:
Cut the meat into thick cubes.
    Heat a pan with a generous amount of oil or fat over high heat. Add the meat cubes and brown them on all sides until they develop a golden-brown color.
    Add sliced onions to the pan and continue cooking over low heat, stirring occasionally, to prevent the onions from burning.
    Once the onions have softened, season the meat with salt. You can also lightly dust the meat with flour for added thickness and flavor.
    After 10 minutes of cooking, pour in about 1/2 cup of water or broth.
    Cover the pan with a lid and simmer the goulash on low heat for another 15 minutes or until the meat becomes tender.
    Check the meat for doneness and adjust the seasoning if necessary.
    Serve the goulash hot with your choice of side dishes, such as potatoes, noodles, or bread.

Goulash is a hearty and flavorful dish that can be enjoyed on its own or paired with other accompaniments. Enjoy your homemade goulash!

Ingredients:
150 grams of meat (beef, pork, or a combination)
    Salt
    Onion
    Flour (optional)
    Water or broth
    1 tablespoon of tomato paste
    Paprika
    Water (to adjust consistency)
    Optional: 1 tablespoon of sour cream
Instructions:
Follow the initial steps of the previous goulash recipe: cut the meat into cubes, brown it in a pan with oil or fat, add sliced onions, and cook until the onions soften.
    Season the meat and onions with salt. You can also lightly dust the meat with flour if desired.
    Add 1 tablespoon of tomato paste and a pinch of paprika to the pan. Stir well to incorporate the flavors.
    If the sauce becomes too thick, add 1-2 tablespoons of water and bring it to a boil. This will help to adjust the consistency.
    Continue to simmer the goulash on low heat for about 15 minutes or until the meat is tender and the flavors have melded together.
    If desired, stir in 1 tablespoon of sour cream to add creaminess to the sauce. This step is optional but common in Hungarian-style goulash.
    Adjust the seasoning if needed.
    Serve the goulash hot with your choice of side dishes, such as potatoes, noodles, or bread.

This variation adds tomato paste, paprika, and the option of sour cream to create a richer and more distinct Hungarian-style goulash. Enjoy your delicious goulash!

Ingredients:
1/2 liter of cold water
    Carrot
    Parsnip
    Celery
    Optional: 1/2 small onion
    Optional: 2 grains of allspice
    Salt
    Optional: 1 teaspoon of vinegar
    Cod fillet
    Butter
    Hard-boiled egg (half for garnish, half for salad)
    Chopped parsley (for garnish)
    Optional: Side dish of boiled potatoes or rice
Instructions:
In a pot, add the cleaned carrot, parsnip, celery, and onion (if using) to 1/2 liter of cold water. You can also add 2 grains of allspice for additional flavor (optional).
    Bring the water with the vegetables to a boil and let them simmer covered for about 20 minutes.
    Strain the vegetable broth and return it to the pot. You can use the cooked vegetables to make a vegetable salad for dinner if desired.
    Season the broth with salt to taste and add 1 teaspoon of vinegar (optional).
    Place the cod fillet into the boiling broth, cover the pot, and simmer on low heat for 15-20 minutes, depending on the size of the fillet. The fish should be cooked until it flakes easily.
    Carefully remove the cooked cod from the broth using a slotted spoon and transfer it to a serving plate.
    Pour melted butter over the cod without browning it and sprinkle finely chopped hard-boiled egg on top. Reserve the other half of the egg for the vegetable salad.
    Garnish with chopped parsley.
    Serve the boiled cod with boiled potatoes or rice. You can sprinkle the potatoes with finely chopped parsley for added flavor.
    Alternatively, instead of garnishing with butter and egg, you can serve the boiled cod with one of the following sauces: Supreme, Mornay, or Poulette (refer to "Sauces" for recipes).
    Be cautious while eating to avoid swallowing any fish bones.
    Leave the skin of the cod, as it becomes tender during cooking, along with the bones, on the plate.

Enjoy your boiled cod meal, either with the classic butter and egg garnish or with a delicious sauce!

Ingredients:
Cleaned cod meat
    Soaked bread crumbs
    Raw egg
    Half a finely chopped and lightly fried onion (should not be browned)
    Butter or margarine for frying the onion
    Salt
    Optional: Pepper
    Optional: Teaspoon of semolina (if needed to thicken the mixture)
    Vegetable broth (prepared according to the previous recipe)
    Dill sauce or horseradish sauce (see "Sauces" for basic white sauce recipe)
    Boiled potatoes or baked rice
Instructions:
Pass the cleaned cod meat through a meat grinder or finely chop it.
    Add soaked and squeezed bread crumbs, raw egg, finely chopped and lightly fried onion.
    Season with salt and optionally pepper. Mix all the ingredients together until you have a homogeneous mixture.
    If the mixture is too loose, add a heaping teaspoon of semolina and mix again.
    Shape the mixture into small egg-sized balls (wet your hands with cold water before shaping) and place them in the boiling vegetable broth (prepared according to the previous recipe).
    Cook the fish meatballs on low heat for about 20 minutes.
    Meanwhile, prepare dill sauce or horseradish sauce based on the basic white sauce recipe.
    Remove the cooked fish meatballs from the broth and pour the sauce over them on a plate.
    Serve the cod meatballs with boiled potatoes or baked rice.

Enjoy your meal!

Ingredients:
Fillet of cod
    Salt
    Lemon juice or vinegar (optional)
    Flour
    Ground pepper
    Lard, cooking oil, or margarine
    Potatoes (for serving)
    Optional accompaniments: Carrot, horseradish, pickled cucumber, sauerkraut, or ingredients for horseradish sauce
Instructions:
Prepare the cod fillet for frying. Season it with salt and, if desired, sprinkle it lightly with lemon juice or vinegar.
    Lightly coat the fillet with flour, ensuring it is evenly covered.
    Heat a tablespoon of lard, cooking oil, or margarine in a frying pan over high heat.
    Place the coated fillet on the hot frying pan. It's important to fry it on a medium heat for about 5 minutes on each side.
    After frying for 5 minutes on each side, cover the pan with a lid and reduce the heat to a minimum. You can also place an asbestos plate on the pan to retain heat. Let the fillet cook for an additional 2-3 minutes to allow it to finish cooking.
    Once cooked, transfer the fried fillet and serve it on a plate.
    Pour the remaining fat from the frying pan over the fillet and potatoes (if serving).
    Accompany the fried cod fillet with a side dish of your choice, such as carrot and horseradish salad, pickled cucumber, sauerkraut, or horseradish sauce (not all at once, of course!).

Enjoy your delicious fried cod fillet meal!

Ingredients:
Cod fillets
    Flour
    Eggs
    Breadcrumbs
    Cooking oil (for frying)
    Salt and pepper (to taste, optional)
Instructions:
Lightly dust the cod fillet with flour.
    Dip the fillet into beaten egg, ensuring it is coated evenly.
    Coat the fillet with breadcrumbs, pressing gently to adhere them to the surface.
    Heat a generous amount of cooking oil in a frying pan over high heat.
    Fry the breaded fillet on high heat for approximately 3 minutes on each side, or until golden brown.
    Reduce the heat to low and continue frying for an additional 3 minutes on each side.
    Cover the frying pan with a lid and let it cook on the lowest heat setting, preferably using an asbestos plate, for another 2 minutes.
    Remove the fried cod fillet from the pan and place it on a serving plate.
    Serve the breaded cod fillet with a side dish of your choice. It pairs well with more piquant vegetables. A touch of grated horseradish (without any additional spices) makes a wonderful complement to this delicious dish. Alternatively, you can prepare a carrot and horseradish salad, sauerkraut salad, or potato salad (if not serving boiled potatoes). This breaded cod is also tasty when served cold.
    Enjoy your breaded fried cod!

Receipe: baked cod in a baking dish
Ingredients:
Thick cod fillet
    Butter
    Salt
    Lemon juice or dry white wine (optional)
    Thick horseradish sauce (refer to "Sauces" for recipes)
    Cooked potatoes (optional)
Instructions:
Preheat the oven to a moderate temperature.
    Place the cod fillet in the baking dish.
    Drizzle a tablespoon of melted butter over the fillet and sprinkle it with salt.
    Bake the cod in the preheated oven for 30 minutes.
    Optionally, you can drizzle the fillet with a teaspoon of lemon juice or dry white wine for variation.
    After 30 minutes, open the baking dish and pour thick horseradish sauce over the fillet. Spread it evenly.
    Return the dish to the oven and bake for an additional 15 minutes.
    If desired, you can also add cooked potatoes to the baking dish and lightly drizzle them with butter. Do not pour sauce over the potatoes.

    Next, add the raw egg yolk to the bowl.

    Begin whisking or stirring the mixture in one direction only. You can use a spoon, a wooden pestle, or a porcelain pestle like those used in pharmacies for grinding ointments.

    As you stir, gradually add a few drops of oil at a time. It's important that the egg yolk and oil are not too cold to prevent the mayonnaise from splitting. Room temperature ingredients work best.

    Continue adding the oil, a few drops at a time, while continuously stirring in one direction. Another person can help by slowly pouring the oil while you stir.

    If the mayonnaise starts to separate or "curdle," it means it has emulsified incorrectly. To fix this, add a tablespoon of hot water while continuing to stir. This should help bring the mixture back together.

    Once you've achieved the desired consistency, adjust the taste by adding more salt, sugar, or lemon juice/vinegar if needed.

    If the mayonnaise is too thick, you can thin it out by adding a tablespoon of sour cream or, as a last resort, water.

    Taste and adjust the seasoning as desired.

    Your homemade mayonnaise sauce is now ready to be used in your favorite dishes or as a dipping sauce.

Remember to store the mayonnaise in a sealed container in the refrigerator and consume it within a few days.

Ingredients:
Cucumber (ripe or slightly yellowish skin)
    Salt
    Olive oil or vegetable oil
    Vinegar or lemon juice
    Pepper
    Fresh dill or chives
    Onion (optional)
    Sour cream (optional)
Instructions:
Peel the cucumber and slice it thinly. If using ripe cucumbers with slightly yellowish skin, they will be sweeter. Do not discard the juice released by the sliced cucumber.
    Lightly sprinkle salt over the sliced cucumber and drizzle it with a tablespoon of olive oil or vegetable oil mixed with vinegar or lemon juice.
    Add a pinch of pepper to the cucumber slices and generously sprinkle them with finely chopped dill or chives.
    Optionally, you can add thinly sliced onion for a more intense flavor. It's a matter of personal preference.
    Toss the cucumber slices gently to coat them evenly with the dressing and herbs.
    Allow the mizeria salad to sit for a few minutes to let the flavors meld together.
    Serve the mizeria salad as a refreshing side dish or accompaniment to main courses.

Remember to always include the chopped dill or chives, as they are essential for the authentic flavor of mizeria. You can also experiment by adding a touch of sour cream to the salad, adjusting the seasoning accordingly.

Enjoy your mizeria salad, a traditional Polish dish!

Ingredients:
2 medium-sized cucumbers
    Salt
    150 grams of crumbled, mildly acidic cheese (such as twaróg or farmer's cheese)
    1/2 cup of sour cream
    Onion, thinly sliced (optional)
    Pepper
    Fresh dill for garnish
Instructions:
Slice the cucumbers into thin rounds and place them in a bowl.
Sprinkle salt over the cucumber slices and let them sit for a few minutes.
After a few minutes, drain any excess liquid from the bowl.
Add the crumbled cheese and sour cream to the cucumbers.
If desired, add thinly sliced onions to the mixture.
Season with a pinch of pepper.
Mix all the ingredients together until well combined.
Let the salad sit for about half an hour before serving to allow the flavors to meld together.
Just before serving, garnish with fresh dill.
